question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for restoring understory plant diversity after logging?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies, several forest management actions have been associated with increases in understory plant richness and/or diversity. Logging/removing trees increased understory plant density/cover in five of 10 studies and increased species richness/diversity in four of seven studies, with other studies reporting no or mixed effects (1273). Season of harvest showed no effect on plant species richness/diversity in one replicated study comparing summer vs winter logging (1216). Thinning trees increased understory density/cover in 17 of 25 studies and increased richness/diversity in 13 of 19 studies, though some studies reported no or mixed effects and one reported decreased herbaceous abundance (1211). Prescribed fire showed mixed outcomes: some studies found increases in cover, density, biomass and richness/diversity, while others found decreases or no effect (1221). Girdling to thin trees increased understory plant species richness, diversity and cover in one before-and-after trial (1226). Vegetation removal combined with mechanical soil disturbance increased understory cover and diversity in two studies and decreased shrub cover in one study; one study also found increased density of young trees (1274). Group-selection harvesting had mixed results, with some studies reporting increased understory cover/diversity and young tree density, and others reporting decreased richness/biomass or no effect (1224). Shelterwood harvesting increased understory abundance, species richness and diversity in six of seven studies, though one study found decreased richness/abundance and another found no effect on tree abundance (1223).
summary_statements: Several forest management actions have been associated with increases in understory plant richness and/or diversity.
In some studies, logging or removing trees increased understory plant density or cover.
In some studies, logging or removing trees increased species richness or diversity.
Other studies on logging or removing trees reported no or mixed effects on understory plants.
One replicated study comparing summer versus winter logging found the season of harvest had no effect on plant species richness or diversity.
In a majority of studies, thinning trees increased understory density or cover.
In a majority of studies, thinning trees increased understory richness or diversity.
Some studies on thinning trees reported no or mixed effects.
One study on thinning trees reported decreased herbaceous abundance.
Prescribed fire showed mixed outcomes on understory plants.
Some studies found that prescribed fire causes increases in understory cover, density, biomass, and richness or diversity.
Some studies found that prescribed fire causes decreases or has no effect on understory plants.
Girdling to thin trees increased understory plant species richness, diversity, and cover in one before-and-after trial.
Vegetation removal combined with mechanical soil disturbance increased understory cover and diversity in some studies.
Vegetation removal combined with mechanical soil disturbance decreased shrub cover in one study.
One study found that vegetation removal combined with mechanical soil disturbance increased the density of young trees.
Group-selection harvesting had mixed results.
Some studies reported that group-selection harvesting increased understory cover, diversity, and young tree density.
Other studies on group-selection harvesting reported decreased richness or biomass, or no effect.
Shelterwood harvesting increased understory abundance, species richness, and diversity in a majority of studies.
One study found that shelterwood harvesting decreased understory richness and abundance.
Another study found that shelterwood harvesting had no effect on tree abundance.

question_details.query: What is the effect of providing education programmes on forest conservation efforts in South America?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In South America, education and awareness initiatives have been associated with improved public attitudes and knowledge toward forest primates in Brazil and Colombia through programmes focused on tamarins [1571]. In Colombia, areas with turtle-related conservation initiatives that included education and awareness reported more people changing consumption habits and fewer people using turtles for food, though stated rates of hunting, buying and selling remained similar [3682].
summary_statements: In South America, education and awareness initiatives have been associated with improved public attitudes toward forest primates in Brazil and Colombia.
In South America, education and awareness initiatives have been associated with improved public knowledge toward forest primates in Brazil and Colombia.
Education and awareness programmes in Brazil and Colombia focused on tamarins.
In Colombia, areas with turtle-related conservation initiatives that included education and awareness reported more people changing consumption habits.
In Colombia, areas with turtle-related conservation initiatives that included education and awareness reported fewer people using turtles for food.
In Colombia, despite turtle-related conservation initiatives, stated rates of hunting, buying and selling of turtles remained similar.
